The President of the Board of Trade gave the Cabinet particulars of the present positionof the Railway Companies as regards coal stocks,together with estimates of the general positionas regards supplies and consumption, and forecasts of the prospects in corning weeks.The Cabinet confirmed the decisions ofthe? Coal Committee on the previous evening,namely: -(i) To request the President of theBoard of Trade to discourage theRailway Companies from announcingor bringing into force any reduo-tions of travelling facilities in the week ending November 7th:. (ii) That the President of the Boardof Trade should have discretion to offer the L, & N.E. RailwayCompany additional coal from.Government sources to the extent,if necessary, of 85,000 tons,conditional on the Company accept-ing the arrangement in (i) above:(iii) In regard to an increase in the ration of household coal.The Prime Minister gave the Cabinet someparticulars of a conversation he had had theprevious evening with representatives of theTrades Union Council, which, however, had notled to any Immediately hopeful result.After further discussion, the cabinet agreed (a) That the Home Secretary should confer with the Attorney-Generaland that they should take appro-priate action if it were foundthat safety men had come out in yorkshire (or elsewhere) in violation of the law:(b) That the Home Secretary, in such manner as he should deem best,should warn the Chief Constablesin disturbed coal areas to keep a careful watch in order to prevent the march of large bodies of minei-s intended to preventminers from working, since this form of intimidation appeared tohavo been particularly successful:(c) That the question of the GoalSituation should be placed on theAgenda for the next Cabinet, andthat any Ministers who had formedviews as to any further action whichthe Government might usefully takeshould be requested to lay them before the Cabinet.-S- 2. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Postmaster-General (Paper CP.-355 (.26))asking for a decision as to whether the newBroadcasting Corporation should be prohibited from broadcasting matters of political, religious or industrial controversy.After considerable discussion, the cabinet agreed (a) That the Postmaster-General shouldnot include in the license to thenew Broadcasting Corporation, forthe present, any provision author-ising them to permit the broadcast-ing of matters of controversy; butthat the Corporation should be leftto do its best to improve theexisting broadcast programmeswithout such powers:(b) That, after an experimental periodof six months, the Postmaster-general should, if necessary, report to theCabinet. 4-.
